channel.title: Decode DC
channel.description: Cut through the language and procedure and focus on what matters.
channel.itunes:author: Mule Radio Syndicate
channel.itunes:summary: Cut through the language and procedure and focus on what matters.
channel.itunes:keywords: politics, capitol hill, congress, andrea seabrook, house of representatives, senate

item.title: 23: Morality 2.0
item.description: Which is worse: breaking the law to leak classified secrets? Or keeping quiet about what could be a violation of Americans' constitutional rights? Andrea Seabrook talks to an expert who believes that these modern times call for a Morality 2.0.
item.content:encoded:
Which is worse: breaking the law to leak classified secrets? Or keeping quiet about what could be a violation of Americans' constitutional rights? Andrea Seabrook talks to an expert who believes that these modern times call for a Morality 2.0.

item.title: 22: Open and Shut Congress
item.description: The government shutdown may be over, but has anything really changed? Andrea talks to Patti Daniels of Vermont Public Radio about the problems that caused the shutdown and which still plague Washington.
item.content:encoded:

item.title: 21: Justice in Shut Down
item.description: Budget battles. Sequestration. And now, shut down. The political mess in Washington has consequences far from Capitol Hill. Andrea talks to a Chief Federal Judge, Loretta A. Preska, about our system of justice teetering on the brink of dysfunction.
item.content:encoded:
Budget battles. Sequestration. And now, shut down. The political mess in Washington has consequences far from Capitol Hill. Andrea talks to a Chief Federal Judge, Loretta A. Preska, about our system of justice teetering on the brink of dysfunction.

item.title: 20: In Other News
item.description: When the news becomes obsessed with a new story every week, do you ever wonder what's being pushed OUT of the headlines? Andrea Seabrook talks to a media critic and a historian about how news outlets choose the most important story, and why they often get it wrong.
item.content:encoded:
When the news becomes obsessed with a new story every week, do you ever wonder what's being pushed OUT of the headlines? Andrea Seabrook talks to a media critic and a historian about how news outlets choose the most important story, and why they often get it wrong.

item.title: 19: Syria's Considerations
item.description: War-drums and peace-cries can drown out more considered implications of US intervention in Syria. We talk about the haunting ghosts of recent wars, plus get a much longer view -- one that advocates the return of mandatory service.
item.content:encoded:
War-drums and peace-cries can drown out more considered implications of US intervention in Syria. We talk about the haunting ghosts of recent wars, plus get a much longer view -- one that advocates the return of mandatory service.

item.title: 15: What's Wrong
item.description: Andrea Seabrook introduces America's best ‘pUNdit’ — a man you'll rarely hear from on the daily news, but who knows more than almost anyone about what's wrong with Washington.

item.description: Rich Tafel was deeply involved in one of the most sweeping changes of recent decades -- the social acceptance of Gay Americans. What's more, he's a Republican.

item.title: 12: Canta Y No Llores
item.description: In the first of a two-part series on immigration, DecodeDC looks at how humor can get closer to a problem than political talking points ever could. Special thanks this week to Radio Ambulante, a Spanish-language radio program telling uniquely Latin American stories.

item.title: 10: A Kind of Republican
item.description: Jim Kolbe, a Republican member of the House of Representatives from 1985–2003, is a political outlier. He is pro-choice, he supports same-sex marriage, and he's against any kind of institutional discrimination. Even more interesting? You probably haven't heard of him.
item.content:encoded:
Jim Kolbe, a Republican member of the House of Representatives from 1985–2003, is a political outlier. He is pro-choice, he supports same-sex marriage, and he's against any kind of institutional discrimination. Even more interesting? You probably haven't heard of him.

item.title: 6: The Future Was Now
item.description: In January, 2012, America's digerati pulled off the broadest, most powerful political protest ever orchestrated on the Internet. One year later we ask, what happened? And what next?
item.content:encoded:

item.title: 5: The Unshow
item.description: What We're NOT Covering and Why. DecodeDC explores the interplay of politics and the media, and how press coverage can feed into the negative, partisan bickering in Washington. Case in point: The Fiscal Cliff.
item.content:encoded:
What We're NOT Covering and Why. DecodeDC explores the interplay of politics and the media, and how press coverage can feed into the negative, partisan bickering in Washington. Case in point: The Fiscal Cliff.

item.title: 4: The Decode DC Voter Guide
item.description: Perhaps the most cockeyed voter guide you've ever heard, this piece intentionally avoids the big issues of this race. Instead, Andrea talks to brilliant thinkers -- among them Michael Pollan (The Omnivore's Dilemma), Lawrence Lessig (The Future of Ideas, One Way Forward: The Outsider's Guide to Fixing the Republic) and Jim Wallis (Sojourners, God's Politics: Why the Right Gets It Wrong and the Left Doesn't Get It) -- about what they're thinking as they head to the voting booth.
item.content:encoded:
Perhaps the most cockeyed voter guide you've ever heard, this piece intentionally avoids the big issues of this race.
